pageContext.claim: “I think mayor of Philadelphia named Frank Rizzo and he had an expression like that. But I've heard it many times. I think it's been used many times. It means two things very different things. One is if there's looting, there's probably going to be shooting. And that's not as a threat. That's really just a fact, because that's what happens. And the other is, if there's looting, there's going to be shooting...But when the looting starts, it oftentimes means there's going to be shooting, there's going to be death, there's going to be killing. And it's a bad thing. And it's also used as a threat.”
pageContext.analysis: The statement was originally coined in 1967 by Miami police Chief Walter Headley, during hearings about crime in the city.
